user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__empty:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__empty (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.tiny)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-T' or '--tiny'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.medium)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-M' or '--medium'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.large)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-L' or '--large'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.empty = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function for uses of the Standard Library function memcmp (the subject of MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14). There are no calls to memcmp in this code fragment. The only string/character operations present are: indexing param_name[1] and comparing that single character to '-' (a direct character comparison), and passing param_name to fprintf (which does not use memcmp). The assignment tool_params.empty = !0 and the conditional checks of tool_params flags likewise do not involve memcmp. Therefore there are no code fragments here that match the Rule 21.14 concern (using memcmp to compare null‑terminated strings) and nothing else in this snippet needs to be flagged for that rule.
